### Brief History
The Jericho 941 is a double action/single action semi-automatic pistol developed by Israel Military Industries. The Jericho 941 was modeled on the well-respected CZ-75 pistol designed and produced by Česká zbrojovka of Czech Republic and built using parts supplied by the Italian arms house Tanfoglio. The Jericho 941 features a polygonal barrel. Magazines for the CZ-75 and Tanfoglio T95 will function in the Jericho 941. One innovation by IMI was a new, much "hotter" cartridge, the .41 Action Express to go along with the Jericho 941. The difference between 9mm and .41 AE is the same as .44 Magnum and .50 AE. The AE bullets have rebated rims which are the same diameter as the less powerful rounds, but the casing is wider, providing more power. This allows these pairs of calibers to be used in the same firearm with only a change of barrel, recoil spring and magazine

postcontent:
Here's a nice piece of Thompson WWII web gear you won't see everyday....a Thompson L-drum pouch.
Most of the pouches had attaching rings on the sides for carrying straps, but early on in the war pouches were made to slide onto the USGI Web belt. They have a loop sewn onto the back with no rings or strap. They were usually carried singly or in pairs and many were marked with the manufacturers (most common were RUSCO). The unmarked pouches are harder to find as fewer were made.

This pouch is one of the rarer unmarked pouches, but is exactly the same color canvas and piping as a pair of RUSCO pouches I have (not for sale) so my guess is this pouch is RUSCO made but unmarked.

It was used and has small rust stains inside in the usual places, the canvas is a bit stretched around the snap but everything is still solid.
The only BAD spots are a small snag on the upper edge (about 10 o'clock) under the flap and a small (pencil-sized) hole around 8 o'clock near the edge. The threads coud be ulled back into the weave with a hook and the area stabilized with a drop of super-glue but I'd leave that to the new owner....and it shows just fine as it is!

Unlike many other used pouches, this one has never been washed so is still in good shape and relatively clean....a nice original GI bringback pouch that will be a nice addition to your collection.

Full power 10MM ammunition has always generated enough pressure to require a pretty stiff recoil spring in your handgun—this of course depends on many variables like your particular slide weight, etc. When the cartridge fires, it generates enough pressure/recoil to prematurely open your breech face in some guns. When this happens, the opening breech has an effect on the burn rate of the powder. This can result in some fairly high extreme velocity spreads. If you are experiencing extreme velocity spreads (in excess of 50 fps) simply install a stiffer recoil spring. For example, I have an original Colt Delta Elite. This Colt, with the factory spring runs extreme spreads of about 35 fps, with this load. I am happy with an ES of 35 fps, so I leave the Delta spring alone. My custom built Para Ordinance 1911, with a Nowlin barrel, runs extreme spreads of about 70 fps, so I installed a recoil spring that was roughly 4 lbs heavier and the extreme spread dropped to about 35 fps. (Wolff Gun Springs—REDACTED-- www.gunsprings.com ) My Glock mod 20 was running extreme spreads of nearly 100 fps, so I installed a 6 lb heavier recoil spring and brought the ES down to 50 fps. The folks at Wolff will tell you what the factory spring rating is for your particular pistol, so you’ll know where to start. I should note, these high ES #'s really don’t matter in the real world as they do not affect accuracy or reliability. The firearms industry fixed this ES problem by watering down 10MM ammo, to the point that most 10MM ammo made by major manufacturers is pretty weak, but it does not open your breech face early…... If weak ammo is the “fix” you want, most any 10MM ammo made by major manufacturers will do. If you wish to shoot our full power 10MM ammo, you can choose to live with the high ES (you’ll only know if you are getting high ES #’s if you use a chronograph) or you can install a stiffer recoil spring.

This load was accurate and reliable in our three test pistols.
